title: Compact Kähler manifolds with nonpositive bisectional curvature

title_detail.value: Compact Kähler manifolds with nonpositive bisectional curvature

summary:
Let $(M^n, g)$ be a compact K\"ahler manifold with nonpositive bisectional
curvature. We show that a finite cover is biholomorphic and isometric to a flat
torus bundle over a compact K\"ahler manifold $N^k$ with $c_1 < 0$. This
confirms a conjecture of Yau. As a corollary, for any compact K\"ahler manifold
with nonpositive bisectional curvature, the Kodaira dimension is equal to the
maximal rank of the Ricci tensor. We also prove a global splitting result under
the assumption of certain immersed complex submanifolds.

summary_detail.value:
Let $(M^n, g)$ be a compact K\"ahler manifold with nonpositive bisectional
curvature. We show that a finite cover is biholomorphic and isometric to a flat
torus bundle over a compact K\"ahler manifold $N^k$ with $c_1 < 0$. This
confirms a conjecture of Yau. As a corollary, for any compact K\"ahler manifold
with nonpositive bisectional curvature, the Kodaira dimension is equal to the
maximal rank of the Ricci tensor. We also prove a global splitting result under
the assumption of certain immersed complex submanifolds.

author: Gang Liu
arxiv_comment: 16 pages, More details added. To appear in GAFA
fulltext:
arXiv:1112.1479v4 [math.DG] 29 Apr 2014

COMPACT KÄHLER MANIFOLDS WITH NONPOSITIVE
BISECTIONAL CURVATURE
GANG LIU

Abstract. Let (M n , g) be a compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive bisectional curvature. We show that a finite cover is biholomorphic and isometric to
a flat torus bundle over a compact Kähler manifold N k with c1 < 0. This confirms a conjecture of Yau. As a corollary, for any compact Kähler manifold with
nonpositive bisectional curvature, the Kodaira dimension is equal to the maximal rank of the Ricci tensor. We also prove a global splitting result under the
assumption of certain immersed complex submanifolds.

1. Introduction
The uniformization theorem of Riemann surfaces says the sign of curvature
could determine the conformal structure in some sense. Explicitly, if the curvature is positive, it is covered by P1 or C. On the other hand, if the curvature is less
than a negative constant, it is covered by the unit disk D2 .
It is natural to wonder whether there are generalizations in higher dimensions.
For the compact case, the famous Frankel conjecture says if a compact Kähler
manifold has positive holomorphic bisectional curvature, then it is biholomorphic
to CPn . This conjecture was solved by Mori [13] and Siu-Yau [15] independently.
In fact Mori proved the stronger Hartshorne conjecture. Later, Mok [12] solved
the generalized Frankel conjecture. The result says that, if a compact Kähler manifold has nonnegative holomorphic bisectional curvature, then the universal cover is
isometric-biholomorphic to (Ck , g0 )×(Pn1 , θ1 )×***×(Pnl , θl )×(M1 , g1 )×***×(Mi , gi ),
where g0 is flat; θk are metrics on Pnk with nonnegative holomorphic bisectional
curvature; (M j , g j ) are compact irreducible Hermitian symmetric spaces.
If the curvature is negative, the current knowledge is much less satisfactory.
For example, a famous conjecture of Yau says if a complete simply connected
Kähler manifold has sectional curvature between two negative constants, then it
is a bounded domain in Cn . So far, it is not even known whether there exists a
nontrivial bounded holomorphic function on such manifolds.
As in the Riemannian case, it is often important to understand the difference
between the negatively curved case and the nonpositive case. The former tends to
be hyperbolic in some sense, while the latter usually possesses some rigidity properties. For compact Kähler manifolds with nonpositive holomorphic bisectional
curvature, there is a conjecture of Yau (page 2 of [17], also [16]):
Conjecture. Let M n be a compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive holomorphic
bisectional curvature. Then there exists a finite cover M ′ of M such that M ′ is
1

 2

GANG LIU

a holomorphic and metric fibre bundle over a compact Kähler manifold N with
nonpositive bisectional curvature and c1 (N) < 0, and the fiber is a flat complex
torus.
Recall that a fiber bundle is called a metric bundle, if for any p ∈ N, there is
some neighborhood p ∈ U ⊂ N such that the bundle over U is isometric to the
product of the fiber with U. In [22], Yau proved the following
Theorem 1. Let M be a compact complex submanifold of a complex torus T n . Then
M is a torus bundle over a complex submanifold N in T n such that the induced
Kähler metric on N has negative definite Ricci tensor in an open dense set of N.
Since complex submanifolds in T n has nonpositive holomorphic bisectional curvature, Yau's theorem confirms the conjecture when M is a complex submanifold
of T n . Zheng [27] proved this conjecture under the extra assumption that M has
nonpositive sectional curvature and the metric is real analytic. In [17], Wu and
Zheng proved this conjecture by only assuming that the metric is real analytic.
They first proved a local splitting result by a careful study of the foliation at the
points where the Ricci tensor has maximal rank. By real analyticity, the foliation
could be extended to the whole manifold. In this note we confirm the conjecture
above.
Theorem 2. Let (M n , g) be a compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive holomorphic bisectional curvature. Then there exists a finite cover M ′ of M such that M ′
is a holomorphic and metric fiber bundle over a compact Kähler manifold N k with
nonpositive bisectional curvature and the Ricci curvature is strict negative in an
open set on N. Thus c1 (N) < 0. The fiber is a flat complex torus T . Furthermore,
M ′ is diffeomorphic to T ×N. Finally, if r is the maximal rank of the Ricci curvature
of g, then r = k = Kod(M) where Kod(M) is the Kodaira dimension of M.
Corollary 1. For any compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive bisectional curvature, the Kodaira dimension is equal to the maximal rank of the Ricci tensor.
Corollary 2. Let M n be a compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive bisectional
curvature. If the Ricci tensor degenerates everywhere, i.e., the maximal rank of the
Ricci tensor is strictly less than n, then the universal cover splits off a nontrivial
complex Euclidean factor holomorphically and isometrically.
One can ask a question similar to corollary 2 in the Riemannian setting. Namely,
for a compact Riemannian manifold with nonpositive sectional curvature, if the
Ricci tensor degenerates everywhere, is it true that the universal cover has a nontrivial Euclidean factor? In Guler and Zheng's paper [7], a counterexample (due
to Gromov) is given. We explain the example in some details (Page 2 in [7]) for
comparison with the Kähler case.
Take a punctured torus Y and equip it with nonpositive curvature such that the
metric near the boundary is isometric to [0, 1] × S1 . Take two copies of Y × S1 and
glue them along the boundary, but with the S1 factors switched. Then the resulting
3-manifold M has nonpositive sectional curvature with Ricci tensor degenerates
everywhere, but the universal cover does not contain an Euclidean factor.

 COMPACT KÄHLER MANIFOLDS WITH NONPOSITIVE BISECTIONAL CURVATURE

3

Similarly a four manifold is obtained if we glue two copies of Y × S1 × S1 by
switching some S1 factors. By theorem 2, this cannot be a counterexample in the
Kähler case. The reason is that if we switch the S1 factor, the metrics match, but
the complex structures do not match!
It is interesting to compare the Riemannian case with the Kähler case. Here we
are assuming that M is a compact (Kähler) manifold with nonpositive sectional
(bisectional) curvature and the Ricci tensor degenerates (If M is only Riemannian,
just ignore the parentheses).
• If M is Riemannian, the universal cover of M does not necessarily have an
Euclidean factor.
• If M is Riemannian with real analytic metric, the universal cover of M does
have a nontrivial Euclidean factor.
• If M is Kähler with real analytic metric, the universal cover of M has a
nontrivial complex Euclidean factor (in metric and holomorphic sense).
• If M is Kähler, the universal cover of M has a nontrivial complex Euclidean
factor (in metric and holomorphic sense).
Among the four conclusions, the first two are given in [7]; the third is proved in
[17]; the last one is corollary 2.
Theorem 3. Let (M n , g) be a compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive holomorphic bisectional curvature. Suppose N n−k ⊂ M is a complete (compact or noncompact) immersed complex submanifold of M which is flat and totally geodesic. If
in addition, Ric(M)|T N = 0, then M splits globally, i.e., the universal cover M̃ is
isometric and biholomorphic to Cn−k × Y k where Y k is a complete Kähler manifold
of dimension k.
Remark. All assumptions in theorem 3 are "local" around N, except that the holomorphic bisectional curvature on M is nonpositive. Thus it might be interesting to
see that local assumptions imply global splitting. Theorem 3 also holds if we assume the manifold has nonnegative bisectional curvature. We can also weaken the
conditions by assuming that M is complete with bounded curvature. Finally, note
that theorem 3 is not true for the Riemannian case.
In [17], Wu and Zheng studied the foliation given by the kernel of the Ricci
tensor at the points where the Ricci tensor has the maximal rank. See section 2,
part 3 for some explanations of this foliation. For 0 ≤ i ≤ n, define U(i) = {x ∈
M|rank(Ric(x)) = i}. If p is an interior point of U(i), then there is a foliation near
p given by the kernel of the Ricci tensor. We can extend the leaves as long as the
points are in the interior of U(i). It is natural to wonder the following:
Question. Will the leaf through p touch the boundary of U(i)?
In [5], Ferus showed that if i is the maximal rank of the Ricci tensor, then the
leaf through p will stay in U(i). Thus it is complete. We have a complete answer
to the question above:
Corollary 3. The leaf through p does not touch the boundary of U(i) if and only if
i the maximal rank of the Ricci tensor on M.

 4

GANG LIU

Next we discuss two applications of theorem 2. The existence of canonical
metrics is a central topic in Kähler geometry. We shall restrict to the case when
c1 ≤ 0. Yau [24] solved the famous Calabi conjecture. He proved that any compact
Kähler manifold with c1 < 0 or c1 = 0 admits a Kähler-Einstein metric. Aubin
[1] also obtained the proof when c1 < 0. It is natural to ask whether there exist
canonical metrics on Kähler manifolds with nonpositive bisectional curvature.
Corollary 4. Let (M n , g0 ) be a compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive holomorphic bisectional curvature. Then the manifold admits a canonical metric g
which is locally a product of a flat metric with a Kähler-Einstein metric with
negative scalar curvature. More precisely, (M, g) is locally biholomorphic and
isometric to (Dn−k , g1 ) × (U k , g2 ). Here k = Kod(M); (Dn−k , g1 ) is a flat complex Euclidean ball with small radius; (U k , g2 ) is a small ball in Ck such that
Ric(g2 ) = −g2 .
Proof. According to theorem 2, there exists a flat fibration T n−k → M ′ → N where
M ′ is a finite cover of M. The universal cover M̃ is biholomorphic to Cn−k × Ñ
where Ñ → N is the universal covering. Since c1 (N) < 0, N admits a unique
Kähler-Einstein metric g2 . Thus Ñ admits a complete Kähler-Einstein metric with
negative scalar curvature. Any element a ∈ π1 (M) induces a deck transformation f
on M̃ which descends to a biholomorphism of Ñ. By Yau's Schwarz lemma [23],
the Kähler-Einstein metric on Ñ is unique. Thus f preserves the Kähler-Einstein
metric g2 on Ñ. Therefore, the product metric on Cn−k × (Ñ, g2 ) descends to a
metric on M which is canonical.

It is also interesting to analyze the long time behavior of the normalized KählerRicci flow
∂gi j
= −Ri j − gi j
(1)
∂t
on such manifolds. Cao [3] proved that if a compact Kähler manifold (M, ω) has
c1 < 0 or c1 = 0 (without normalization), then the Kähler-Ricci flow converges to
a Kähler-Einstein metric. Tsuji [21] and Tian-Zhang [20] proved that if a Kähler
manifold has c1 ≤ 0, then the normalized Kähler-Ricci flow has long time existence. In [18], Song and Tian considered the normalized Kähler-Ricci flow on an
elliptic surface f : X → Σ where some of the fibers may be singular. It was shown
that the flow converges to a generalized Kähler-Einstein metric. This result was
generalized in [19] to the fibration f : X → Xcan where X is a nonsingular algebraic variety with semi-ample canonical bundle and Xcan is its canonical model.
We have a result in the similar spirit.
Corollary 5. Let M n be a compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive bisectional
curvature. Then for any initial Kähler metric g(0), the normalized Kähler-Ricci
flow converges in C ∞ (M) to the Kähler-Einstein metric factor in corollary 4.
Proof. Let M ′ be in theorem 2. We consider the normalized Kähler-Ricci flow
on M ′ which is diffeomorphic to T × N. Recall a theorem of M. Gill [6] which
generalizes a theorem in [14] by Song and Weinkove,

 COMPACT KÄHLER MANIFOLDS WITH NONPOSITIVE BISECTIONAL CURVATURE

5

Theorem 4. Let X = Y × T where Y is a compact Kähler manifold with negative
first Chern class and T is a complex torus. Let ω(t) be the normalized Kähler-Ricci
flow on X with any initial metric ω(0), then ω(t) converges to π∗ (ωY ) in C ∞ (X, ω0 )
sense as t → ∞ where π : X → Y is the projection and ωY is the Kähler-Einstein
metric on Y.
Note that M ′ is not necessarily biholomorphic to T × N. However, M ′ is locally
biholomorphic to T × U where U is an open set in N. Thus there is a flat metric ωT
on the fiber independent of the projection to N. Then one can check that the proof
of theorem 4 in [6] works in this case without any modification. The projection of
the Kähler-Ricci flow from M ′ to M concludes the proof.

The proof of theorem 2 uses Hamilton's Ricci flow [8] and Hamilton's maximum principle for tensors [9][4][2], together with some argument in [17] by Wu
and Zheng. We will use the invariant convex set constructed in [2] by Böhm and
Wilking. The key point is to prove that there exists a small ǫ > 0 such that along
the Ricci flow, Ric(g(t)) ≤ 0 for all 0 < t < ǫ (note that the holomorphic bisectional curvature is not necessarily nonpositive for small t). The final assertion
rank(Ric(g(0))) = k will follow from an argument of Yu [26].
Remark. There is a general philosophy that the Ricci flow makes the curvature
towards positive, e.g., Hamilton-Ivey pinching estimate [10][11]. So it might be
interesting to see that in our case, at least in a short time, the Ricci curvature
remains nonpositive.
Acknowledgements
The author would like to express his deep gratitude to his former advisor, Professor Jiaping Wang, for his kind help and useful suggestions. He also thanks
Professor Fangyang Zheng for his interest in this note. Special thanks also go to
Guoyi Xu, Bo Yang and Yuan Yuan for their helpful comments.
2. Preliminaries

Ricci kernel foliation This part is based on [17], page 266. Let M be a compact
Kähler manifold with nonpositive bisectional curvature. Then the Ricci form is
negative semi-definite. Let r be the maximal (complex) rank of the Ricci form and
U be the open set on M where the rank of Ric is equal to r. Denote by L the
distribution in U given by the kernel of the Ricci tensor.
By linear algebra, the nonpositivity of the bisectional curvature implies that X ∈
L if and only if R(X, ∗, ∗, ∗) ≡ 0, where R is the curvature tensor. So L is the kernel
of the curvature tensor. Thus it is a foliation, whose leaves are totally geodesic, flat
complex submanifolds of U. By a theorem of Ferus [5], each leaf of L is complete.
3. The proof of theorem 2
∂g

Proof. Let g(t) be the solution to the Ricci flow equation ∂ti j = −Rici j with g(0) =
g. Let V be defined as in (4). Following Böhm and Wilking [2], we shall construct
a family of convex sets Vt of V which are invariant under parallel transport and Vt
is invariant under the evolution equation (7) for small t. The precise statement is
the following:
Proposition 1. Let K2 be a positive constant. Then there exist positive constants
K1 , K3 , ǫ depending only on K2 and n such that ǫK1 ≤ 1, ǫK3 ≤ 21 and the following
hold: For t ≥ 0, let Vt be a subset of Kähler curvature operators R in V satisfying
the following conditions:
(1). Ric(α, α) ≤ 0 for any eα ∈ W 1,0 .

Putting Claim 2, proposition 1 and theorem 5 together, we find
Theorem 6. Let (M, g) be compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive bisectional
t
curvature. If gt satisfies the Ricci flow equation ∂g
∂t = −Ric(gt ) and g0 = g, then
there exists ǫ > 0 depending only on the bound of the curvature and the dimension
such that Ric(gt ) ≤ 0 for 0 ≤ t < ǫ.
Remark. The counterpart of theorem 6 is true in the Riemannian case, i.e., if a
compact manifold has nonpositive sectional curvature, then along the Ricci flow,
in a short time, the Ricci curvature remains nonpositive.
Now let us come back to theorem 2. By theorem 6, Ric(g(t)) ≤ 0 for small t > 0.
Following the arguments in [2] (page 676-677), we shall show that the rank of Rict
is constant and the null space is parallel. By (6),

This means the kernel of Rict is invariant for 0 < t < ǫ1 .
By proposition 1, the kernel of the Ricci tensor is the kernel of the curvature
operator. De Rham theorem says the universal cover ( M̃, g(t)) has a flat factor
Cn−k for 0 < t < ǫ1 . By a holonomy argument, the universal cover ( M̃, g0 ) is
biholomorphic and isometric to Cn−k × Y k where Y k is a complete Kähler manifold
with nonpositive bisectional curvature.
Let r be the maximal rank of the Ricci curvature of g = g0 . We follow the
argument in [26] to show that r = k = dim(Y). It is clear that
r ≤ k,

(26)

since the rank of Rict is k for 0 < t ≤ ǫ1 . Recall corollary C in [17] (page 277):
Theorem 7. If M n is a compact Kähler manifold with nonpositive bisectional curvature which has Ricci rank r < n, then the open set U in which the Ricci tensor has
maximum rank r in the universal cover M̃ is, locally, holomorphically isometric to
La × Ya , where La is a complete flat Kähler manifold, and Ya is a Kähler manifold
with nonpositive bisectional curvature and negative Ricci curvature.
We apply theorem 7 to the compact Kähler manifold M in theorem 2. It is
immediate to see that dim(Ya ) = r since Ya has negative Ricci curvature. Let f
be the holomorphic immersion La → M̃ given by theorem 7. By the evolution
equation of the Kähler-Ricci flow,

(28) implies that − R(p, t)dt is a bounded plurisubharmonic function on La . Since

La is flat, the function must be a constant. Therefore Ricii (g(ǫ1 )) = 0 for any
ei ∈ T 1,0 La . Then k = rank of Ric(g(ǫ1 )) ≤ n−dim(La )= n − (n − r) = r. Combining
this with (26), we find r = k. Therefore, for the metric g = g(0), the Ricci curvature
is negative somewhere on Y.
Recall theorem E in [17] (page 278):
Theorem 8. Let M n be a compact Kähler manifold with real analytic metric and
nonpositive bisectional curvature. Denote by r its Ricci rank. Then there exists a
finite covering M ′ of M, such that q : M ′ → N r is a holomorphic fiber bundle over
compact Kähler manifold N r with nonpositive bisectional curvature and c1 (N) < 0,
while the fiber of q is a complex (n − r) torus T .
Furthermore, M ′ is diffeomorphic to N×T , and q is a metric bundle, i.e., ∀x ∈ N,
there exists a small neighborhood x ∈ V ⊂ N such that q−1 V is isometric to T × V.
In Wu and Zheng's proof of theorem E, the real analyticity condition is only
used to show that the universal cover splits as Cn−r × Y r where Y r is a simply
connected, complete Kähler manifold with nonpositive bisectional curvature, and
the Ricci tensor of Y r is negative definite somewhere. Since this is confirmed
without assuming the real analyticity of the metric, Wu and Zheng's proof works
in our case without any modification.
Next we show r = k = Kod(M). Recall theorem 6.10(2) in [25]:
Theorem 9. Let f : V → W be a finite unramified covering of complex manifolds.
Then Kod(V) = Kod(W).
Since M ′ is a finite cover of M, Kod(M) = Kod(M ′ ). Note that pluricanonical
sections on M ′ could be reduced to pluricanonical sections on N. Thus Kod(M ′ ) =
Kod(N) = k, since c1 (N) < 0. The proof of Theorem 2 is complete.

4. The proof of theorem 3
Proof. Let g(t) be the solution to the Kähler-Ricci flow with g(0) = g. Then by
theorem 6, the Ricci curvature will be nonpositive in a short time. By assumption,
N is an immersed totally geodesic flat complex submanifold of M and Ric(M)|T N =
0. Applying equation (28), we find that Ric(M, g(t))|T N vanishes for small t > 0.
Then rank(Ric(g(0)) = rank(Ric(g(t)) ≤ k. By corollary 2, M̃ has a flat factor
Cn−k .

Proof of corollary 3: Let r be the maximal rank of the Ricci tensor of M. We
only need to prove that if the leaf Ln−i through p stays in the interior of U(i), then
i = r. In this case, Ln−i must be a complete totally geodesic immersed complex
submanifold in M such that Ric(M)|T L = 0. By theorem 3, the universal cover of
M splits off a factor Cn−i . Thus r ≤ n − (n − i) = i. The proof of corollary 3 is
complete.
